questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is no family history of serious illness. He works as an engineer at a local company. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. He drinks one glass of red wine every other day. His only medication is metformin. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a soft, nontender abdomen. The liver is palpated 2 to 3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show an aspartate aminotransferase concentration of 100 U/L and an alanine aminotransferase concentration of 130 U/L. Liver biopsy shows hepatocyte ballooning degeneration, as well as inflammatory infiltrates with scattered lymphocytes, neutrophils, and Kupffer cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Primary biliary cirrhosis is often an incidental finding when asymptomatic hepatomegaly and elevated cholestasis parameters (ALP, GGT, conjugated bilirubin) are detected during routine examinations. Elevated antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA) support the diagnosis. Transaminases are typically within normal limits or slightly elevated. Liver biopsy would show portal lymphocytic infiltration, periductal granulomas, and bile duct changes. Primary biliary cirrhosis rarely occurs in men and based on this patient's history, another diagnosis is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Alcohol-associated steatosis is an early stage of alcohol-associated liver disease. Although this patient has a history of moderate alcohol consumption, alcohol-associated steatosis is generally associated with the consumption of ≥ 3 drinks per day or ≥ 21 per week in men. Laboratory findings of alcohol-associated steatosis show elevated transaminase, in which AST > ALT. A distinction between alcohol-associated steatosis and metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis is often difficult but can be drawn based on patient history as well as serum carbohydrate-deficient transferrin levels. Furthermore, liver biopsy in alcohol-associated steatosis typically shows Mallory bodies as well as microvesicular and macrovesicular steatosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute viral hepatitis could be responsible for this patient's hepatomegaly and elevated transaminase levels, but other features such as fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice would also be expected. As in this patient, ALT levels are greater than AST levels (AST/ALT ratio < 1), but serum transaminase levels would likely be highly elevated (400–1000 U). Furthermore, liver biopsy would show portal inflammatory infiltrates and lobular necrosis. Considering this patient's history of T2DM and obesity as well as the lack of signs of acute viral hepatitis, he most likely has a different liver condition.

D) CORRECT:

Metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH) is a common finding in patients with obesity and/or T2DM (metabolic syndrome). Excess supply of nutrients causes progressive accumulation of triglycerides in the liver, which eventually triggers inflammation with an increased risk of cirrhosis. Patients are often asymptomatic, but early signs can include hepatomegaly on physical exam and elevated transaminases (AST/ALT ratio < 1). The liver biopsy of this patient also shows characteristic findings of MASH. Progression to cirrhosis can be prevented by optimizing T2DM treatment and lifestyle changes (e.g., weight loss).

E) INCORRECT:

Hemochromatosis can cause asymptomatic hepatomegaly with elevated serum transaminase as well as diabetes mellitus. However, other features, such as hyperpigmentation of the skin, cardiomyopathy, and arthralgia would also be expected. Elevated serum ferritin levels would support the diagnosis. Additionally, liver biopsy would show pronounced hepatocyte siderosis in iron staining.

F) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis is a rare form of chronic hepatitis that could be responsible for this patient's asymptomatic hepatomegaly and elevated transaminase levels. However, it predominantly affects women and is often associated with other autoimmune conditions (e.g., T1DM, celiac disease). More importantly, liver biopsy would show a periportal inflammatory process with plasma cell infiltrates and bile duct changes. Based on this patient's history and biopsy findings, he most likely has a different liver condition.
questions.hint: This obese patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) presents with asymptomatic hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases (AST/ALT ratio < 1). Hepatocyte ballooning degeneration and inflammatory infiltrates on liver biopsy are likely to be accompanied by pure macrovesicular steatosis.

A 42-year-old man comes to the physician to establish care. He recently moved to the area and has not been to a primary care physician for over 5 years. He has no history of serious illness but has intermittent bilateral knee pain for which he takes 650 mg acetaminophen every other day. He is married with three children and is sexually active with his wife. During the past 10 years, he has unsuccessfully tried to lose weight. He has smoked one half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. About 2–3 times per week he has 1–2 glasses of wine with dinner. He is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall and weighs 93 kg (205 lb); BMI is 36 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. The liver is palpated 2–3 cm below the right costal margin. Laboratory studies show:

Transabdominal ultrasonography shows a mildly enlarged, diffusely hyperechoic liver. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's hepatic abnormalities?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic viral hepatitis can result in an elevation of liver transaminase enzymes, AST/ALT ratio < 1, hepatomegaly, as well as diffuse hepatic steatosis on ultrasonography. However, laboratory studies in this patient indicate that the patient does not have hepatitis B or C infection, which are responsible for the overwhelming majority of chronic viral hepatitis. The positive HbsAb titers in this patient are a result of prior immunization. Moreover, this patient does not have risk factors for hepatitis B or C infection (e.g., multiple blood transfusions, injection drug use), which makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis typically occurs between the ages of 40 and 60 years and results in elevation of liver transaminase enzymes and hepatomegaly. However, negative ANA (< 1:20 is not significant among adults), negative ASMA, and negative anti-LKM-1 titers rule out autoimmune hepatitis. Also, autoimmune hepatitis is much more common among women.

C) INCORRECT:

Congestive hepatopathy can result in mild hepatomegaly with diffuse hyperechogenicity and mildly increased liver transaminase levels. However, congestive hepatopathy occurs as a result of congestive heart failure, tricuspid regurgitation, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and/or constrictive pericarditis. The absence of clinical features such as dyspnea, peripheral edema, ascites, and murmur make these conditions unlikely. Moreover, ultrasonography would also show dilated hepatic veins, which has not been reported in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

This patient with obesity and abnormal hepatic findings on laboratory studies and ultrasonography most likely has nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH). Although the underlying mechanism of NASH is not fully understood, insulin resistance is believed to play a major role in hepatic lipid accumulation. Adipokines released from fat deposits decrease the insulin sensitivity of peripheral tissue, which causes postprandial hyperglycemia and a consequent increase in insulin secretion. This hyperinsulinemia triggers lipid uptake as well as lipogenesis within hepatocytes (nonalcoholic steatosis). The precursors of triglycerides (e.g., fatty acids, glycerols) and the byproducts of lipid metabolism can cause hepatocellular damage (NASH) by inducing oxidative stress. Chronic hepatocellular damage eventually leads to cirrhosis and an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.

NASH is only diagnosed in patients with no history of heavy alcohol use and after other causes of chronic liver disease have been ruled out. Besides obesity, major risk factors for developing NASH include diabetes mellitus (this patient's elevated HbA1c of 6.3% indicates prediabetes) and hypertriglyceridemia. Other known risk factors for NASH are parenteral nutrition and certain medications, such as amiodarone, tamoxifen, and antiretroviral drugs.

E) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen is not hepatotoxic if the total daily dose is less than 7 g/day.

F) INCORRECT:

Heavy alcohol use can result in alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD), which can result in elevation of liver transaminase enzymes, hepatomegaly, as well as diffuse hepatic steatosis on ultrasonography. However, in patients with ALD, serum AST levels are typically greater than ALT levels. Moreover, a weekly alcohol consumption of less than 6 units does not constitute heavy alcohol use.
questions.hint: This patient's ultrasonographic findings suggest hepatic steatosis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man with type 2 diabetes, hyperlipidemia, and obesity is referred for evaluation of persistently abnormal liver enzyme levels. His efforts to lose weight have not been successful. He consumes less than one alcoholic beverage per month.
On examination, his blood pressure is 145/89 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 76 beats per minute. His BMI is 31. His abdomen is soft and nontender. His liver is of normal size, and his spleen is slightly enlarged on palpation.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range



Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
185
0–35



Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
75
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
75
30–120


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
1.0
0.3–1.0



Platelet count (per mm3)
100,000
150,000–350,000



Hematocrit (%)
39.0
41.0–53.0


Testing for hepatitis C antibody, hepatitis B surface antigen, and autoantibodies is negative. Transferrin saturation levels are normal. His Fibrosis-4 score is calculated to be 3.03.
Ultrasound of the right upper quadrant reveals diffuse fatty infiltration of the liver and slight enlargement of the spleen.
In addition to recommending weight loss and exercise, which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Imaging of the liver, such as with CT or MRI, is not a reliable indicator of the presence of steatohepatitis or fibrosis.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) can have simple steatosis or steatohepatitis; those with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis are at risk for advanced fibrosis, cirrhosis, liver failure, and liver cancer. The best way to distinguish the subtypes of NAFLD and assess for complications is to obtain a liver biopsy. However, this procedure is expensive and has procedure-related morbidity; in addition, other than weight loss, effective treatment options are limited. Liver biopsy is therefore used only in certain circumstances - namely in patients who have a high risk for advanced fibrosis and in whom the diagnosis of NAFLD is uncertain.

This patient has evidence of more advanced disease, with thrombocytopenia and splenomegaly. His calculated Fibrosis-4 score is 3.03, which suggests that he is at high risk for advanced fibrosis. He should be referred to a hepatologist for consideration of additional risk stratification with noninvasive tests, such as liver stiffness measurement by elastography or enhanced liver-fibrosis bloodletting. A liver biopsy is likely not necessary; the diagnosis of NAFLD is not in doubt, given the patient's multiple risk factors for this condition (diabetes, obesity, hyperlipidemia), and thus, the risks of an invasive procedure outweigh any potential benefit.

Key learning point: In a patient with a likely diagnosis of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease who is at high risk for advanced fibrosis based on an elevated Fibrosis-4 score, the best next step in management is referral to a hepatologist.

C) INCORRECT:

Although vitamin E may be beneficial in patients with steatohepatitis, it has not been studied in patients with type 2 diabetes.

D) INCORRECT:

Repeat testing of liver enzyme levels in 6 months is not appropriate because aminotransferase levels are not reliable indicators of the presence of steatohepatitis or fibrosis. In NAFLD, alanine aminotransferase levels are typically higher than aspartate aminotransferase levels; however, with the development of fibrosis, this ratio often reverses.

E) INCORRECT:

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery is indicated for the treatment of obesity in patients who have a BMI >40 or who have a BMI >35 in the presence of serious comorbidities, such as type 2 diabetes. This patient, who has a BMI of 31, is therefore not a candidate for such surgery. However, the clinician may reasonably consider a diabetes management strategy that can assist with weight loss, specifically incorporating the use of a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist, which has been shown to improve liver histology in patients with NAFLD. Pioglitazone is another antidiabetic agent with proven benefit in NAFLD, although it is associated with weight gain.

He lives in an apartment with his wife and identified himself as white on the patient intake questionnaire.
On examination, his BMI is 33, his vital signs are within normal limits, and he has no signs of acute or chronic liver disease.

A complete blood count and serum creatinine level are normal. Tests for hepatitis B surface antigen and hepatitis C antibodies are negative.
Which one of the following additional tests is most appropriate for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Because a hepatic manifestation of Wilson disease is extremely unlikely in a 65-year-old person, serum ceruloplasmin testing is unnecessary.

B) CORRECT:

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a common cause of asymptomatic aminotransferase elevations and chronic liver disease in Western populations, with diagnoses ranging from simple steatosis to fibrosing steatohepatitis that progresses to cirrhosis. Obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes or prediabetes, and hyperlipidemia are associated with NAFLD.

The diagnosis of NAFLD is one of exclusion; substantial alcohol consumption and viral hepatitis infection must be ruled out. Studies to exclude other causes of aminotransferase elevations should be performed selectively, depending on disease probabilities in a given patient. Hemochromatosis is sufficiently common in older men of European ancestry to warrant serum ferritin and transferrin saturation studies in this case. Once other disorders are ruled out by laboratory evaluation, an ultrasound examination of the right upper quadrant can be performed to assess for findings suggestive of NAFLD, such as a hyperechoic liver parenchyma.

The role and timing of liver biopsy in the diagnosis of NAFLD is controversial because the procedure is costly and associated with procedure-related morbidity. In addition, effective therapeutic options other than weight loss are limited. A biopsy is often considered when there is uncertainty about the diagnosis or when there is clinical evidence of advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis. In this case, the best next step is to assess for other common causes of elevated aminotransferases before considering a biopsy.

Key learning point: Before a diagnosis of nonalcoholic fatty liver disease can be made, other causes of liver disease such as substantial alcohol consumption, hepatotoxic medication intake, and viral hepatitis need to be ruled out in all patients. Further testing can be adapted to the clinical scenario but in older men should include testing for hemochromatosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Antimitochondrial antibodies are found in patients with primary biliary cholangitis (previously referred to as primary biliary cirrhosis), a cholestatic disorder associated with alkaline phosphatase elevation.

D) INCORRECT:

Autoimmune hepatitis (characterized by antinuclear antibodies and anti-smooth-muscle antibodies) most often occurs in middle-aged women; it is less likely than hemochromatosis in a 65-year-old man of European ancestry.

E) INCORRECT:

Liver biopsy is not indicated in an asymptomatic patient with mild elevations in aminotransferases.

The role and timing of liver biopsy in the diagnosis of NAFLD is controversial because the procedure is costly and associated with procedure-related morbidity. In addition, effective therapeutic options other than weight loss are limited. A biopsy is often considered when there is uncertainty about the diagnosis or when there is clinical evidence of advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis. In this case, the best next step is to assess for other common causes of elevated aminotransferases before considering a biopsy.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy with no notable medical history presents for a routine health maintenance examination. His mother reports that he is doing well and that she has no specific concerns. The boy performs well in school and plays baseball.
A review of systems is negative. The patient has a normal appetite and eats three meals a day, with snacks between meals. He drinks water, whole milk, and fruit juice. His father has hypertension and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH); his mother has type 2 diabetes.
His vital signs are normal except for his systolic blood pressure, which is at the 95th percentile for his age; his diastolic blood pressure is at the 80th percentile. His height is at the 75th percentile, with a normal height velocity; his BMI is at the 96th percentile. Physical examination is normal, with the exception of acanthosis nigricans on the neck.
In addition to a lipid profile and glycated hemoglobin level, which one of the following tests should be ordered for this patient at this time?

choices.text: Thyroid-stimulating hormone and free thyroxine levels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chromosomal microarray is useful for detecting some genetic causes of disease and would be helpful in a patient with suspected Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS). This patient is developing normally with normal tone, making PWS unlikely.

B) CORRECT:

Given his obesity and family history of nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), this patient is at risk for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and should be screened accordingly.

NAFLD — defined as chronic hepatic steatosis in the absence of other identifiable causes — manifests on a spectrum, ranging from the mere presence of excess fat in the liver (nonalcoholic fatty liver) to the development of inflammation (NASH). Chronic inflammation may develop into fibrosis and, ultimately, end-stage liver failure. Unfortunately, the natural course of this disease is unpredictable, and NAFLD may be more aggressive in children than in adults.

The prevalence of NAFLD is increasing as rates of obesity rise. The vast majority of patients with NAFLD are asymptomatic, although some may experience mild, occasional abdominal pain or fatigue.

Screening for NAFLD is recommended in all children and adolescents with a BMI ≥95thpercentile for their age — and in those with a BMI ≥85th percentile plus other risk factors (e.g., insulin resistance, prediabetes, diabetes, lipid abnormalities, obstructive sleep apnea, hypopituitarism, family history of NAFLD or NASH).

The preferred screening test for NAFLD is measurement of the alanine aminotransferase (ALT) level, which is universally available, cost-effective, and noninvasive. Although it is not specific for NAFLD, an ALT level two times the upper limit of normal has a sensitivity of 88% for detecting NAFLD. A standardized upper limit of normal of 26 U/liter for males and 22 U/liters for females should be used rather than a specific laboratory reference value. NAFLD remains a diagnosis of exclusion, which requires ruling out other genetic, infectious, drug-induced, or metabolic causes of chronic hepatitis.

Key learning point: All children and adolescents with a BMI ≥95th percentile should undergo screening for nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) using measurement of serum alanine aminotransferase levels.

C) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasound can identify liver steatosis but is more expensive and has a lower sensitivity and specificity than measuring the ALT level; hence, it is not a recommended screening test for NAFLD. Without specific symptoms of hepatobiliary disease, such as pain in the right upper quadrant, ultrasound is not warranted.

D) INCORRECT:

Although thyroid disease can lead to obesity, it is unlikely in this case, as the patient has an unremarkable medical history and normal physical examination, with normal growth velocity. Thyroid disease should be considered in children with obesity who have growth deceleration, declining school performance, or other symptoms suggestive of hypothyroidism.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient’s obesity and family history also put him at risk for hypertension. Indeed, his systolic blood pressure (BP) is at the 95th percentile for his age. Although ambulatory BP monitoring is an important part of investigating hypertension, it is not yet warranted in a patient who has had only one abnormal BP reading. Repeat BP measurements and lifestyle changes are indicated first.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents for evaluation of persistent fatigue and mild right upper quadrant discomfort. He has type 2 diabetes controlled on oral medication and denies alcohol use. His BMI is 35. Laboratory tests reveal mildly elevated aminotransferases. Abdominal ultrasound shows diffuse echogenicity of the liver consistent with fatty infiltration. He is concerned about his risk of disease progression (see report).
Abdominal ultrasound: Diffuse echogenicity of the liver consistent with fatty infiltration
Which intervention is most likely to attenuate progression of his liver disease?

choices.text: Sustained weight reduction through structured lifestyle measures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) is used in cholestatic liver diseases like primary biliary cholangitis, where it improves bile flow. However, in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), driven by metabolic factors like obesity and type 2 diabetes, UDCA has not shown significant benefits in reducing hepatic steatosis, inflammation, or fibrosis.

B) CORRECT:

In non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), excess weight is a key modifiable risk factor contributing to hepatic steatosis via insulin resistance and increased free fatty acid flux to the liver. Sustained weight loss through structured lifestyle measures, including dietary changes, physical activity, and behavioral interventions, improves liver enzyme abnormalities and histologic features by reducing hepatic lipid accumulation and improving insulin sensitivity. A moderate weight reduction of 7-10% of baseline body weight can significantly improve steatosis, inflammation, and fibrosis, reducing progression to non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH).

Key learning point: Weight loss is the most effective intervention to prevent the progression of non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) by reducing liver fat, inflammation, and fibrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

High-dose vitamin E has shown histologic improvement in non-diabetic patients with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. However, its benefit in diabetic patients is limited, as their fatty liver disease is linked to insulin resistance and metabolic dysregulation. Additionally, high-dose vitamin E carries risks, such as hemorrhagic complications, making it less suitable for patients with significant metabolic comorbidities.

D) INCORRECT:

Fibrates activate peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPARα), enhancing triglyceride catabolism and modestly increasing HDL cholesterol. They are used for hypertriglyceridemia to reduce cardiovascular risk. However, in nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), characterized by obesity and type 2 diabetes, lifestyle interventions are more effective than fibrates, which lack robust evidence for modifying NAFLD progression.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man presents for a routine check-up. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes and is currently on metformin and a sulfonylurea. He complains of mild fatigue but no other symptoms. He does not consume alcohol and denies a family history of liver disease. His BMI is 32 kg/m². Laboratory testing reveals elevated ALT and AST levels. A fasting lipid panel shows elevated triglycerides and low HDL cholesterol (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Alanine aminotransferase
65 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Aspartate aminotransferase
40 IU/L
12 - 40 IU/L


Alkaline phosphatase
80 IU/L
39 - 117 IU/L



Abdominal ultrasound: Increased hepatic echogenicity
Which is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Advise weight reduction through diet and exercise

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Liver biopsy is reserved for uncertain diagnoses or suspected progressive liver disease. This patient's findings suggest NAFLD, which is initially managed with lifestyle changes and metabolic risk factor control. Mild enzyme elevations and no signs of advanced liver injury do not warrant an urgent biopsy, given the procedure's risks.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin E has shown benefits in nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) in non-diabetic individuals. However, this patient has type 2 diabetes and features of NAFLD, not confirmed NASH. Without biopsy-proven inflammation or fibrosis, vitamin E is not indicated. Lifestyle changes and glycemic control are more effective for managing metabolic disturbances in diabetic patients.

C) CORRECT:

Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is associated with insulin resistance, obesity, type 2 diabetes, and dyslipidemia. The patient's elevated alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and increased hepatic echogenicity on ultrasound suggest hepatic steatosis, a feature of NAFLD. Lifestyle modification, including weight reduction through diet and exercise, is the primary management strategy. A 5-10% reduction in body weight can decrease hepatic fat, improve liver enzymes, and enhance insulin sensitivity. This approach also addresses metabolic syndrome components, reducing cardiovascular risk.

Key learning point: In patients with diabetes mellitus, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a common cause of abnormal liver function tests due to its association with insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) is used in cholestatic liver diseases like primary biliary cholangitis. This patient has features of hepatic steatosis, not a cholestatic process. Normal alkaline phosphatase and the absence of cholestatic changes further support this. UDCA is not supported for metabolic-associated liver disease, where lifestyle modifications are more effective.

Acute viral hepatitis could be responsible for this patient's hepatomegaly and elevated transaminase levels, but other features such as fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, right upper quadrant pain, and jaundice would also be expected. As in this patient, ALT levels are greater than AST levels (AST/ALT ratio < 1), but serum transaminase levels would likely be highly elevated (400–1000 U). Furthermore, liver biopsy would show portal inflammatory infiltrates and lobular necrosis. Considering this patient's history of T2DM and obesity as well as the lack of signs of acute viral hepatitis, he most likely has a different liver condition.
questions.hint: This obese patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) presents with asymptomatic hepatomegaly and elevated transaminases (AST/ALT ratio < 1).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 1-week history of right upper quadrant discomfort. His medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and central obesity. He takes metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin. He drinks 2–3 beers per week and denies heavier alcohol use in the past. He denies recent medication changes or travel. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination shows mild hepatomegaly but is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory studies show AST 85 U/L (normal 10–40 U/L), ALT 95 U/L (normal 10–40 U/L), and normal bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase. Complete blood count and basic metabolic panel are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute viral hepatitis typically manifests with higher transaminase levels; another diagnosis is more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

While the patient does consume alcohol, an intake of 2–3 beers per week is considered light alcohol consumption and is unlikely to cause alcohol-associated liver disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Although hemochromatosis can cause elevated hepatocellular enzymes and hepatomegaly, this diagnosis requires evidence of iron overload and often occurs in patients with a family history or specific genetic mutations. Moreover, hemochromatosis typically manifests with elevated serum ferritin and transferrin saturation as key diagnostic markers. Another more common diagnosis is more likely in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's medications (metformin, enalapril, and atorvastatin) are not commonly associated with hepatic steatosis or significant liver injury. Furthermore, drug-induced liver injury typically occurs in temporal association with medication initiation or dose changes, but this patient has had no recent medication changes.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has multiple cardiometabolic risk factors including hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, dyslipidemia, and central obesity. These are criteria for metabolic syndrome. Mild hepatomegaly with moderately elevated transaminases in a patient with metabolic syndrome, combined with negative viral serologies and light alcohol use, strongly suggests metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis, a subtype of metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease characterized by chronic hepatocellular inflammation and damage.
